newsitem.title: USA: US, EU meet on meat inspection as deadline nears.
newsitem.headline: US, EU meet on meat inspection as deadline nears.

text.p: Negotiators from the United States and European Union are meeting to work on a nettlesome meat inspection dispute that may disrupt transatlantic trade from April 1.

Several hundred million dollars in beef, pork and poultry exports and imports were at stake in the discussions over so-called veterinary equivalency rules. An agreement would allow each side to accept meat from the other even if they disagree on particulars of how to assure the meat is safe.
"There could be trade disruption on both sides," said Paul Drazek, trade advisor to Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman.
The dispute has run for years. An interim agreement was to expire last December 31 but 90 additional days were granted for further efforts.

Last week, an EU official in Brussels said the talks on mutual recognition of standards were in trouble. On the same day, the EU reduced by 30 percent its list of U.S. poultry plants that met its requirements.
The EU has said it would implement new veterinary and sanitary controls on April 1. The United States has said it might retaliate for any cut-back in access to EU markets.

Talks began on Monday and were scheduled to continue on Tuesday and Wednesday. Discussions began on the technical level but, in view of the impending deadline and the intractable nature of some of the disagreements, might require high-level attention.
Lars Hoelgaard was head of the EU team. The U.S. team included representatives of the U.S. trade representative's office, the Food and Drug Administration and the Agriculture Department.
